Journal.Title: Water science and technology : a journal of the International Association on Water Pollution Research

Article.ArticleTitle: Ozonation of nursing home wastewater pretreated in a membrane bioreactor.

AbstractText: Nursing home (NH) wastewater was pretreated in an ultrafiltration membrane bioreactor (MBR) and subsequently ozonated in a pilot plant in order to evaluate the elimination of pharmaceutically active compounds (PhACs). Dosing of the pre-treated wastewater with 5 mg ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) L<sup>-1</sup> led to the elimination of >50% for nearly all investigated PhACs in the ozonation plant, whereas dosing 10 mg O<sub>3</sub> L<sup>-1</sup> increased elimination to >80%. A total hydraulic retention time of 12.8 min proved sufficient for PhAC elimination. Specific ozone consumption and influent dissolved organic carbon (DOC) (8.2-9.5 mg L<sup>-1</sup>) were in similar ranges for all three performed trials. Combining the MBR with subsequent ozonation at a dosage of 5 mg O<sub>3</sub> L<sup>-1</sup> achieved elimination of >90% and effluent concentrations below 250 ng L<sup>-1</sup> for nearly all the investigated PhACs. Influent concentrations of the MBR were comparable to those found in municipal wastewater. Thus, the recommended dosage for PhAC elimination of 5 mg O<sub>3</sub> L<sup>-1</sup> (i.e. a specific consumption of 0.6 g O<sub>3</sub>*(g DOC)<sup>-1</sup>) is in the same range as for municipal wastewater. However, due to a smaller plant size, the specific costs for treating NH wastewater would significantly exceed those of treating municipal wastewater.
